FORMER SAF CAMP IN DOVER ROAD/VACANT LAND NEAR BUONA VISTA MRT STATION
(Development plan)


    1. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for National Development what is the future development plan for the former Singapore Armed Forces camp area in Dover Road and the vacant land near the Buona Vista Mass Rapid Transit Station.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of National Development is preparing a plan to guide the long term development of the Ayer Rajah area bounded by Clementi Road, Pasir Panjang Road, the railway line and Alexandra Road. In this plan, we will take advantage of the special assets of the area, ie, the National University of Singapore, Science Park, the greenery and hilly terrain of the area. STATUTORY LIMITATION ON TAXIS


    3. Mr Lew Syn Pau asked the Minister for Communications and Information if he will consider extending the 7-year statutory lifespan of taxis.

     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Sir, in asking Question No.3, may I also declare my interest in this subject.

Column: 747



     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, taxis are used very intensively for many hours on our roads each day. Therefore, for the safety and convenience of taxi commuters as well as other road users, they should be roadworthy and well-maintained.

    The annual mileage clocked by a taxi is on the average about 138,000 km, that is seven times that of an average car which is about 19,000 km per year. In other words, a 7-year old taxi would have covered as much mileage as a car in its 50th year and would be subjected to corresponding wear and tear on parts that are not replaced. The percentage of 3-year old taxis which pass their statutory inspections at first inspection is 67%. That is about the same as that for 9-year old private cars. Similarly, the passing rate for taxis in their sixth year is much lower than that of cars much older than 10 years old. In view of that, the Government does not intend to extend the 7-year statutory limitation on taxis.

Column: 748

SALARY REVISION FOR POLITICAL,
JUDICIAL AND RELATED APPOINTMENTS
(Statement by the First Deputy Prime Minister)


     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Trade and Industry announced the salary revision for the Civil Service last Friday. Along with it, the Government has decided to revise the salaries of political, judicial, and other statutory appointments. I shall deal first with the political appointments which include the Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Ministers, Ministers, Ministers of State, Parliamentary Secretaries,

Column: 749

Political Secretaries and Members of Parliament.

Need for the best to form the Government

    There are 81 Members of Parliament, excluding the Non-Constituency MP. From them, we appoint the Prime Minister and other Cabinet Ministers. Presently, the Cabinet has 13 Ministers. These 13 men are responsible for policies which affect every aspect of our lives. Their decisions determine what kind of homes we live in, what kind of education our children have, and whether we receive good medical treatment should we fall sick. Their economic and financial policies affect our job, and our take-home pay. Their effectiveness in maintaining security and upholding law and order enable all of us to sleep soundly at night. Their foresight and judgment and their ability to solve acute problems, both long term and immediate, determine our future. If we want the right decisions to be taken for Singapore, we must continue to get the right people to do the job.

    Let me illustrate this with a simple example. Almost every Singapore family has savings in the CPF. Our total CPF savings amount to a colossal $33 billion. To let you understand what this size means, let me give you their equivalent of housing units. This sum of money can buy 626,000 4-room type HDB flats, at a price of $54,000 per flat. This is equivalent to our being able to buy all the HDB flats that have been built so far by the Government. Suppose we have an incompetent, dishonest, spendthrift, Government. They may fail to attract investments, and then economic growth will falter. They will not balance the budget year after year, and we have to dig into the reserves. They may invest the reserves unwisely or they may dip their fingers into the till, as Marcos did in the Philippines. Then, your CPF savings will be devalued, or even wiped out, long before you can get them on retirement.

    Every Singaporean has a vested interest in making sure that the honest and the able stand for elections and that the best of them form the government. Every one of Singapore's Ministers must come from the top of their cohorts, not just academically-

Column: 750

although this is definitely useful-but also in proven performance.

    At each General Election, we need 15 to 20 new Members of Parliament, just to replace those who are getting older. Amongst the new MPs, we need two or three who will make good Ministers. These two or three must be amongst the best in Singapore, in terms of ability, character and motivation. They must have the intellectual and moral calibre to govern Singapore.

    About 50,000 babies are born each year. We are looking for two or three Ministers every five years, which means in between elections we are looking for two or three Ministers out of an election cohort of a quarter million Singaporeans - 50,000 times five. That means we are looking for that one man in every 100,000 Singaporeans. When it comes to the Prime Minister, we can count ourselves lucky if we can produce one in every 10 or 20 years!

    By dint of enormous effort, we have succeeded in building a small team of Ministers, just a small team. I can say that nearly every Minister in the present Cabinet was among the top 50 students of their year. So were many of our MPs.

    Many of the Ministers were, in fact, President Scholars, which means that they were among the top 10 of their year. Let me give you some names. Dr Yeo Ning Hong- he was one of the nine State Scholars (this was the predecessor to the President Scholarship); Lee Yock Suan- one of nine President Scholars in 1966; Mah Bow Tan-one of seven President Scholars in 1967; Lee Hsien Loong-one of eight in 1970; George Yeo-one of 11 1973. And they were at the top of their class in the best universities, competing against the best in UK and, in some cases, Australia.

Difficulties of Recruiting Political Talent

    We need more Ministers like them, more at each election. But such men are increasingly difficult to recruit. I know the difficulties because I have been talent scouting for the Government ever since I was elected in 1976. Those whom we want

Column: 751

in the Cabinet are invariably successful people. If they were not successful, why should we want to invite them to join us and enter politics?

    Unfortunately, successful Singaporeans are seldom eager to enter politics. That is a fact of life in Singapore. They do not believe that the future of Singapore depends on their being in politics. They are content to leave the country in the hands of other honest and capable people so that they can follow their own private careers in peace. They know that however successful they may have been in their careers, going into politics is a risk, the risk of failure to meet a challenge of an altogether different kind. Because even if they can manage a Ministry well, they may not be able to handle the sensitive political issues dealing with people's lives, their hopes and fears. The brighter they are, the more clearly they understand that to succeed they must have that feel for people, that ability to sway people and galvanize them into action, that something called political leadership.

    Putting aside any loss in salaries, why should they give up the certainty of a good career and a good future in a profession, or a bank, or a big company or the Civil Service, for the uncertainty of ministerial office? Why should they give up their privacy and subject themselves to the glare of publicity? Why should they spend more time with voters when they need the time to spend with their families? Why should they be called upon when others can do it? Why should they do it when others are running the government so well, and they, like everyone else, are enjoying the fruits of economic progress?

Examples of Reluctant Politicians

    Do you know how many times I had to see Dr Richard Hu, Wong Kan Seng, George Yeo, Mah Bow Tan and Seet Ai Mee before they said "yes"? At least three times each, and over many months. I remember Richard Hu seeing me in my office, looking thoroughly miserable, and I was looking just as miserable because I was not able to get good men (this was in

Column: 752

1984). I told him I needed a Finance Minister. He said, "But you have got Dr Tony Tan." Dhanabalan, and Dr Goh Keng Swee were still around at that time. I then explained that Dr Tony Tan, then Finance Minister, would be needed him to run the Education Ministry. I think Dr Tan was the Finance Minister at that time. Then, it dawned upon Dr Richard Hu that Dr Goh Keng Swee was retiring because I talked about Tony Tan going over to the Education Ministry.And I think that gave him little choice. He said "yes". He realized I could not just find a Finance Minister in 1984 to take over from Dr Tan. Dhanabalan was required in the Foreign Ministry.

    I got them to say "yes"-Dr Richard Hu, Wong Kan Seng, and the others because I persisted and appealed to their sense of duty, duty to their fellow citizens, to their friends and relatives and to their own family. They did not volunteer to serve. They were called up. They finally agreed because of a sense of service to the nation. Evenif we had paid them more than what they were earning, they would still not have come in without intense persuasion. It is therefore necessary to minimize the sacrifice that a person is asked to make, and minimizing the financial sacrifice is the least we should do.

    Peter Sung was persuaded to stand in a different way. Dhanabalan recruited him. Dhanabalan asked Peter Sung in 1984; Peter declined. Then Peter was sent to the Philippines as our Ambassador. Whilst he was in the Philippines, he realized that if good men did not come forward to serve, the country would go down. So when Dhanabalan approached him again in 1988, Peter said yes.

    Although I am a persistent person when it comes to talent scouting for the Government, I have not always been successful in recruiting good candidates. For example, there is a young man out there in the private sector who would make a top-rate Minister. He works for a multi-national company. I failed to persuade him to stand in the last General Election. I must have tried over half a dozen times, but he stood firm. One of the reasons was the heavy sacrifice this would mean to his family life. He does not like publicity, and neither does

Column: 753

his wife. And they saw no reason whatsoever to forgo privacy for the family. But another reason why he was reluctant was because he was locked in by his company's stock option scheme. And he would have lost several hundred thousand dollars had he resigned to stand for elections. Why should he resign? Why should he? I do not blame him for saying no. But I have not given up yet. I am going to send Peter Sung to see him and bring him to the Philippines, if necessary.

    I also failed to persuade a public accountant to stand as a candidate for elections to be a Member of Parliament. He works in an international firm. His firm disallows its employees to take part in politics, as a matter of policy. To contest the elections, he had to resign and forgo an annual income of over half a million dollars. It did not make sense to him or to me that he should resign just to be a Member of Parliament. The sacrifice is simply too great.

Rationale for Salary Revision

    People who enter politics in order to get rich are unfit to be Ministers. Let me make that quite clear. If you think that the salary is so attractive that you want to be a Minister because of the salaries, you are unlikely to pass our screening test. We are not interested in people who come into politics because of what they perceive as a handsome salary. But why should we require able Singaporeans who are fit to be Ministers to make a large financial sacrifice in order to enter politics? If we demand this of them, why should able men enter politics at all? If Singapore is to continue to have able men in Government, we must at least ensure that after having sacrificed their privacy, leisure and family time, such people do not also have to make too large a financial sacrifice. This is the rationale for the current salary revision.

Salary Revision of Political Office-Holders

    Salaries of political office-holders were last revised in 1981. But because of rapid

Column: 754

economic growth, they still lag well behind incomes in the private sector. I shall now ask the Clerk of Parliament to circulate a table which I call Annex A*. It is the same table which was released when the Civil Service Pay Revision was announced last week. But I think it is useful to refresh your memory. [Copies of table circulated to Members].

    The table shows typical salaries of top executives and professionals in the private sector in 1987. If you look at the table, you will notice that not only are these numbers much larger than civil service salaries, they even exceed the salaries of Ministers. This disparity will make it harder for us to recruit men and women of ability and integrity into Government, and to maintain the quality of political leadership. This is the reason for adjusting the salaries now.

Structure of Salary Revision

    I shall now deal with the structure of the salary revision. The components of the salary revision parallel those for Superscale officers in the Administrative service, namely:

    (a) Higher salary grades for each appointment;

    (b) A half-month increase in the existing end-of-year non-pensionable variable bonus, bringing it to 1ª months;

    (c) A new discretionary non-pensionable performance-based bonus of up to two months of salary; and

    (d) Promotional grades for Senior Parliamentary Secretaries, Ministers of State, Senior Ministers of State and Cabinet Ministers.

Higher Salary Grades

    Now I shall ask the Clerk of Parliament to distribute Annex B (Cols. 833 - 834). Annex B gives the details of the new basic salaries. Salaries of political office-holders are expressed in terms of Civil Service Superscale and Staff Grade points. The Government will now attach higher grades to the various

Column: 755

appointments. For example, let us look at the Ministers. Ministers are now on Staff Grade I plus 5%. They will move to Staff Grade II plus 10%. In addition, the new grades will carry the revised Civil Service basic salaries, so that they will be worth 7% more than before. You remember that the Superscale Civil Service salaries were revised by 7%. These two changes will increase the basic salaries of the various posts.
Annex B - MONTHLY SALARIES (Cols. 833 - 834)


    We have raised the grades for Ministers, and this will give more room for promoting civil servants. By creating the new Staff Grades IV and V, we will preserve the existing correct relativities between top civil servants and political posts. After the revision, a Staff Grade V Administrative Officer will earn more than any Minister except the Prime Minister, just as a Staff Grade III officer does today. In other words, we are retaining the relativity.

    In percentage terms, this increase in basic salaries may appear to be large. But in spite of this increase, Ministers' salaries will still be modest compared to the professions listed in the table which I handed out earlier, Annex A.

    A Minister's revised monthly salary at $22,100 basic, which when you gross up becomes $28,644, including NWC, is less than the top incomes in any of the professions in Annex A. Even the Prime Minister's revised salary at $38,275 basic, which when you gross up becomes $49,608 per month, will still be far less than what a top doctor or lawyer can earn, and no more than what the Chief Executive Officer of a large local manufacturing company can expect. Top doctors earn on average $93,000; top lawyers over $100,000 per month. So the Prime Minister's salary falls far behind them.

Variable Bonus

    On variable bonus, political office-holders will get the same additional 1/2 month of variable bonus. This, of course, depends on the state of the economy, just like civil service salaries on the variable bonus.

Column: 756



Performance Bonus

    We have introduced a performance bonus for Superscale civil servants. Ministers, Ministers of State, Parliamentary Secretaries and Political Secretaries will likewise receive a performance bonus of up to two months of salary, varying from individual to individual, like the Superscale officers in the Administrative Service.

    The Prime Minister will receive the full two months as a fixed arrangement. He will decide how much each Minister, Parliamentary Secretary and Political Secretary should receive. And his decisions will be kept confidential. So would the amount paid to each person.

Promotional Grades

    Now I come to promotional grades. The Government has also decided to create promotional grades within the ranks of Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Minister of State, Senior Minister of State and Minister. Why are we doing this? It is because promotion from Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State, Minister and upwards is a route which few can take. The leaps in responsibility are just far too large. Promotion grades within each rank allow us to reward a Parliamentary Secretary or Minister by promotion to a higher salary grade when he does his job well. Despite providing for promotion grades, let me say that a political career is not iron-clad. It is fraught with the vagaries of the ballot as well as the risk of making political blunders. In other words, you cannot plan on the basis of a steady career or progression in your career in the political service. But promotion grades will allow us to reward those who continue, and contribute, in office for many years.

    Now I shall deal with the details of the various grades.

Senior Parliamentary Secretaries

    First, Senior Parliamentary Secretaries. Senior Parliamentary Secretaries are presently on Grade E. This will be revised to E1, and an additional grade point of D will be added.

Column: 757



Ministers of State

    The Minister of State grade is currently Superscale Grade C, and the Senior Minister of State is Superscale Grade B. There will be three grades for Ministers of State: D1, C and B; and three for Senior Ministers of State: B, A and Staff Grade I. The overlap at Grade B is a transitional arrangement. These additional grades, especially the higher grades for Senior Ministers of State, will enable office-holders to have a full political career without necessarily becoming full Cabinet Ministers. Such men can make important contributions at the Ministry level, managing complex departments and making operational decisions requiring long experience and intimate knowledge of their field. We need more such people to reinforce our team. Hence the provision of promotional grades for them.

Ministers

    Ministers will move from Staff Grade I plus 5% to Staff Grade II plus 10%. There is also a promotional grade for Ministers. The promotional point will be Staff Grade IV. Ministers will be appointed to the higher grade on a personal basis. Ministerial responsibilities differ considerably in scope. Those carrying heavier portfolios should be paid more. The higher point will enable us to recognize this and pay them properly without having to move up the salaries of each Minister. We will not be attaching new appointment titles to the new grades. There will be no difference in title or address between those on the higher and lower grades, whether they are Ministers, Ministers of State, or Senior Parliamentary Secretaries. In other words, we will continue to address a Minister a Minister even though he is on a higher grade. We have the term "Senior Minister" but this term will continue to be reserved for special individuals, like Mr Rajaratnam.

Conversion

    After this revision, all current appointment holders will be placed onto their corresponding new grade points. I do not intend to promote any Minister, Minister of State, or Parliamentary Secretaries to the higher grades immediately. I will do so only later, when I judge it necessary.

Column: 758



Make-up Pay for Ministers

    Even with the higher salary grades for Ministers, we will still want from time to time to induct successful and able men from the private sector into the Cabinet, men who are earning far more than the revised pay for Ministers, to serve for one or perhaps two terms. If such a person has first to be tried out for a period as a Minister of State before being appointed a full Minister, the problem becomes more acute.

    To accommodate these possibilities without upsetting the protocol order, the Government is introducing a system of make-up pay, similar to that practised with reservist national servicemen.

    In future when a Minister or a Minister of State is appointed, he may receive make-up pay in addition to his rank pay. In other words, if he earns more than that of a Minister of State and he is appointed as a Minister of State, the difference will be paid to him by way of a make-up pay, but he will not receive the entire difference. He will receive only up to 90% of that difference. The calculation will be based on his income tax returns for the last two years before his appointment. The make-up pay will not be carried on for ever. A Minister can continue to receive this for up to two terms of office. In other words, after two terms the make-up pay will be removed because after that he either returns to the private sector or continues on his rank pay alone without this make-up pay.

    We are introducing this system of make-up pay because I believe this will enable the country to benefit from the services of those who do not wish to make politics their entire career, but who have a contribution to make to the nation. They can now become Ministers without having to make too much of a sacrifice.

    The system of make-up pay will not apply to existing office-holders. It will be used primarily to induct successful people between 35 and 45 years of age to be tried out as Ministers of State before they are appointed as Ministers.

Column: 759



MPs' Allowances

    Members of Parliament currently receive a tax-free basic allowance of $3,000 a month (gross $3,850). This will be increased to $4,000 a month (gross $5,184).

    In addition to the MPs' allowance, MPs will be allowed to reclaim reimbursement of up to $750 a month, to defray the wages of a legislative assistant and a secretary. Several MPs can club together to engage a young graduate (e.g. one who is doing his Masters or Ph.D) as a legislative assistant, plus a secretary. The legislative assistant can help the MPs to research issues and look up facts, so that MPs can be better prepared for public speeches and Parliamentary debates. The secretary is to help the MPs to despatch constituency work. Such help may make it easier to get good men to run for Parliament.

    Most mature legislatures provide such support to their members. For example, British Members of Parliament and US Congressmen have legislative assistants. Because in a developing country situation, you need a leader of a Ministry or a department who not only understands the ordinary arguments for or against, but at the end of it says, "Look, will this work, given our circumstances? Never mind what the British, what the Australians, what the New Zealanders do. This is Singapore. Will it work in this situation?" And it is the leader with the political touch, with the rough and tumble of people, who has to decide.

    We had to build an Army, Navy and Air Force from scratch from a population of 2.1-2.2 million, at the time we started. I took my best Minister and said, "I'd stop Finance. We'll make a living. Lim Kim San, you take over. Keep it going. Goh Keng Swee run it. Build it from scratch." His only experience was as a corporal in the Volunteers. But I would like to see any Chief of Staff stand up to him and argue on hardware, on strategy, on tactics. He taught himself. And to make sure that I understood him, he made sure that I also read at least the basics of what he has read. I was inundated. What is a company, what is a platoon, battalion, brigades, divisions, who does what? You get a Permanent Secretary to do that? We studied systems-Israel, Switzerland, Sweden. But finally we worked out our own, and it is working.

    But the most difficult part is to find new Goh Keng Swees, new Hon Sui Sens, new Rajaratnams, Toh Chin Chyes, Lim Kim Sans. Because if you lose that sharp cutting edge, your Permanent Secretary cannot save you. It has happened over and over again. Why are we different? Because we fielded our best team in the political

Column: 810

hot seat. It is much easier to be a Permanent Secretary. "Don't have to worry about answering either the Member for Potong Pasir or the Non-Constituency Member. These are my recommendations. They are logical. It's been done in these following countries. That is your choice, Minister. Choose." The theory that you can have anybody elected to office in Singapore and it will carry on is just stupendously stupid. It will not. And the Permanent Secretaries are the first ones to tell you that. They know. You can have it in Britain and America. Their leaders are good communicators. To be elected you have to be. But they make no bones about it. You see the way the American Press treated President Reagan. Hands off President, dozing off at Cabinet meetings, not interested, goes to sleep early. That is not the point. In that system, do you want to be President? For years you go around the country pumping hands, making speeches, to get support, and if you are no good at the television screen you are out. Good PR, then you win. The rest, you pick bright Secretaries who are prepared to give up their jobs. Like George Schultz who gave up his job as Chief Executive of Bechtel in California to become Secretary of State for 6(r) years. For a pittance. Yes, but then that is their system. I urge you to take a hard headed approach.

    There are a few points which deserve reply. Is it an abandonment of the idealistic approach for the materialistic? No. It is an adaptation to new conditions. Tan Teck Chwee refused to accept that the younger generation had different options from his. They defeated him. Let me recount one example. He was able and determined. We were short of good teachers. So he persuaded a young man, a President's Scholar, to take up Mathematics, sent him to a top university and be a teacher. The young man came back and said, "I want to join the Administrative Service." He said, "No, teaching is a good profession. I started life as a teacher. You see where that got me?" So the young man became a teacher, not at the university but at a junior college. Within a few years the young man had arranged for somebody to buy him out. So we lost. We had a teacher for a paltry few years and a big company got a man of some worth. I can repeat that umpteen

Column: 811

times, the market decides it. We had created a situation in which it is no longer possible to tell the young man: you will follow this. Indeed that was what was available to Tan Teck Chwee - there were two jobs in the Civil Service and only two a year. Other than that you are a teacher or you try and run a small shop. Chou En-lai, 100% and others 50%? Chou En-lai and China are in trouble. A generation that sacrificed everything, finds its children vulnerable to the good things in life, and finds their successor-generation also wanting the good life; and they do not know how to stamp out corruption. It is so vast. Anybody who goes to Hong Kong regularly, as I do, knows that if you want to do business you must learn to do what? The Hong Kong merchants and entrepreneurs arrange, they have to arrange, for many things, including the education of the top cadres with whom they deal, education of their children in America, because that is what they want. Says Dr Lee Siew-Choh, but that was only because they decided to follow capitalist methods, that in the days of Chairman Mao things were much better. That just is not true. In the days of Chairman Mao there were less opportunities because there were very few avenues for enterprise but the people who will return you, your discarded old sock or your ball pen, are specially selected to look after foreign guests, foreign visitors. We are all the product of our times and indeed not to recognize that would mean a collapse of what we have achieved so far.

    Dr Lee says it is wrong to compare the public sector with the private sector. Are we differently wired in our minds? One does not need to eat, to live, to send his children to university? The other does? You are born differently, one AC, the other DC?

    He talks glibly of British judges and QCs. I happen to know because that was my profession. You got a top QC to become a judge after he has had his innings at the Bar, and at the ripe old age or young age of 50+, before 60, he takes his last top income, tax free, and then goes on the Bench. That got cancelled when Labour got into office in the 1970's, and they had

Column: 812

problems. So now they have upped the salaries and they give them handsome pensions. So you take on a judgeship and carry on till 75, and you live happily ever after and you live for a very long time on indexed pensions. But those are the values of another society.

    I have tried to get people to be judges in Singapore. Again and again I poured through the list. It does matter, and to pretend that it does not is to make the system malfunction. In short, this will not be the last time you are going to face it. In three to four years time, Goh Chok Tong and his committee will have to find another 15 to 20 good men and women to replace those who are older, and amongst the 15 to 20 there should be three potential Ministers. In the end, if one survives the attrition, that is not bad, because there is no guarantee that because you are a successful executive, therefore, you are a successful Minister. They are different. Aptitudes are required. You have to be good plus a touch not only with a camera but with people.

    Mr Chiam may not be able to add or subtract quickly, but he can get a pocket calculator to do that for him. But he knows that if he starts looking very sincere and raises his voice, then a lot of people in Potong Pasir will cheer for him, whatever he says. Our job is to slowly educate the people so that finally they know that this is all a charade, that this is a joke, that he is going through the motions. He cannot get anybody worthwhile to stand for elections for the SDP. He knows that. He has admitted that as much. It is a problem. Yes, I concede it is a problem for him as it is for us. More difficult for him, of course, because he is a committee of one; we are a committee of 20, 30, on our side. Dedication? Albert Schweitzer? Don't bother. Start off with a ball picker and maybe, if he picks good balls, you might make him into a tennis star for the SDP! Or better still, get a few good caddies, and you might turn up for the Singapore Open in golf. But for the PAP, before we take them in, we like those whose score should be at least below 80 for one round. Otherwise, don't try.

     Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar GRC)( In Mandarin): Mr Chairman, during the

Column: 813

debate on the budget statement I stated that I support the move to increase the salaries for the Ministers. We must change the strange mentality of some people like Mr Chiam See Tong and Dr Lee Siew-Choh of "wanting the horse to be good, yet not wanting the horse to eat the grass." If we want to attract talented people to serve the nation we must not expect the Ministers to make too much sacrifices. Today in the big companies and in the banks, the salaries of the Chief Executives are many times more than those of our Ministers. Most people feel that under such leadership if the company can prosper and do well, then the future is promising. As such, it will not only be good to the company, it will also benefit all the workers. To such people, paying high salaries to these executives is justificable! However, once we talk about increasing the Ministers' salaries, some people like Chiam See Tong and Lee Siew Choh will say that we should not talk about money. "If we talk about money we lose our feelings for each other." But we must not forget that the Ministers' duties and responsibilities are very heavy and difficult. They have to look after not just a company, a clinic or a law firm, but a country with 2.6 million people and the survival of the country. Let us just put aside their heavy responsibilities for the time being and just take a look at our reserves. We have $33.3 billion in our reserves, but now we are only increasing their salaries by $43 million. It is only 0.012% of our reserves. We must change this strange attitude of "No to Ministers' pay rise, but all right to an increase of salaries for others" in order to attract more talented people to serve the nation.

    Mr Chairman, if we compare the value of our Singapore dollars which has been enhanced and strengthen from year to year and the interest enjoyed by our reserves, we would realize that 0.012% increase in the Minister's salary is indeed negligible! No doubt, in many countries, their Ministers' salaries are very low, yet their currencies are being devalued again and again, to the extent of 30 to 50%, in the end it is the people who suffer! In order to have an honest, frank and efficient government, I support the motion to increase the Ministers' salaries. However, I

Column: 814

hope the First Deputy Prime Minister will reconsider the two following points:

    First, the system of "make-up pay" to attract talents. Why don't we have a higher and uniform salary for Ministers to attract them, because with such a "make-up pay" it will result in a lack of uniformity in the Ministers' salaries and the difference can be very great. Although the second generation leaders are agreeable to this monetary incentive scheme of "giving heavy rewards to attract courageous people". I fear that the 3rd generation, 4th generation or even our future poliical leaders may, as a result of which be at odds with each other and be uncooperative with each other. There may even exist the feeling of being "lost". If there is such a phenomenon, then it will greatly reduce the cohesiveness among our Cabinet ministers, and it will do our nation no good.

    Secondly, about the performance bonus of two months' salary to the Ministers, it may also give rise to some problems because if we award some ministers and do not award others, then there may be problems because performance appraisal is quite subjective. Because some human weaknesses, some Ministers may have some feeling of discontent and indirectly resulting in the lack of cohesiveness and coordination in the Cabinet. For this reason, I suggest that we award a fixed performance bonus to the Ministers. If possible, give the Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Ministers and Senior Ministers a fixed bonus of two months, 1(r) months bonus for the Ministers and one month for the Ministers of State. This is certainly better than causing bad feelings among the members in the Cabinet as a result of some subjective appraisal system. I believe, by so doing, we would be able to maintain the spirit of cooperation which we have enjoyed all along in the PAP Government. Thank you.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, before I make my observations, I just want to make a couple of points in reply to the Non-Constituency MP, Dr Lee. He said that in 1958 when he was asked to stand as a PAP candidate in Kallang he was afraid of the ISA. I do not think that is quite correct

Column: 815

because in 1958, Sir, there was no ISA. There was the PPSO (Preservation of Public Security Ordinance).

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Splitting hairs.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: I am not splitting hairs. That is what he said-"the ISA was used as a trump card." These are his exact words. So he cannot deny that. Strange enough, Sir, in 1959 he stood as a PAP candidate and that was when the PAP came to power. However, in 1963, he led the Barisan Sosialis and I, for the first time, stood as a PAP candidate in the 1963 general elections. This has got something to do with what he said-"that he has never changed." I will show that he has changed.

    In 1963, the results of the general elections showed that the Barisan captured only 13 of the 51 seats. They became an Opposition but the NCMP himself was not in this House. In 1966, the Barisan went out of Parliament and took up extra parliamentary struggle, and for some time the NCMP decided not to take part in elections. But strange enough in the 1970s, he stood again. But when he said he did not change, I do not believe him because in the 1988 general elections he led his Party into the Workers Party and stood as a Workers Party candidate. I leave it to the House to see whether what he said is correct or not.

    But, Sir, let me come to the substance of today's debate. I have had a look at the last few copies of Hansard on salary increases for Ministers, MPs' allowance, judiciary and the lot. Therefore, I wish to commend the First Deputy Prime Minister for being frank and forthright in putting this problem in the right perspective by coming to grips with it and putting it to the nation. We all know that the second team led by the First Deputy Prime Minister-he was elected First Deputy Prime Minister after the 1984 elections by his peers and unanimously endorsed by all the PAP MPs-is now well placed to see Singapore through into the 21st century which is some 10 years or less to come.

    Sir, in tabling the recommendations, effective from 1st April, the First Deputy

Column: 816

Prime Minister pointed out the difficulty in recruiting fresh talents. By "fresh talents" I think he meant, amongst other things, getting younger men and women into the political leadership and that was the problem he and his team faced in the last two general elections.

    In my view, these recommendations for a revision in the salaries have got something to do more with the building up of a third team. I have spoken to quite a number of Ministers whom I know very well. They are not very particular about the salary revision for themselves but I can foresee that the problem is getting the third team. Before coming to the third team, may I say something of the second team because I know quite a number of the Ministers who helped to form the second team.

    If I recall to mind, in 1970, the PAP took on self-renewal, how to replace themselves by injecting fresh blood, better men and women into the Party. Looking at the second team, I would just like to describe a few of them. In 1972, the Second Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Ong Teng Cheong, a successful architect came in. So 1972-89, he and Dr Ahmad Mattar. In 1976, we had the First Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong. He was, I think, holding the post of Managing Director in Neptune Orient Lines and we also had the Minister for National Development, Mr Dhanabalan, who was Senior Executive Vice-President of the DBS. So 1976, two. Then in 1979, we have the Minister for Education, Dr Tony Tan, who was then General Manager of OCBC. Then, of course, in 1980 we had a couple more, the Minister for Home Affairs and Law, Prof. Jayakumar, who was also Singapore's Permanent Representative to the United Nations when he gave up his professorship at the Law Faculty, and also the Minister for Communications and Information, Dr Yeo Ning Hong, who was holding one of the top posts in a multi-national company. If we add them together, the Front Bench has 13, there are six with the Prime Minister, who of course is from the first generation.

    Sir, what I am trying to say is that this process of a self-renewal and a careful and

Column: 817

cautious selection of a team takes a long time, more than 10 years, to get a second team in place. But, that is not the end of it. What is more important is how this team will gel to become one team and to lead the nation forward. In my view, the problem that the second team under the charge of the First Deputy Prime Minister, who will in time to come take over as Prime Minister, will then have to settle the problem of looking for a third team. I do not think that within a span of five-seven years he could get that third team in place. But if he could, as the Prime Minister has said, for Ministers of State up to Cabinet Minister, maybe with a low attrition, yes. But if the salary revision is not realistic enough to make it more bearable and more acceptable to those who want to come into the political leadership, I think it will be more than hypocritical of us to just ignore this change of time. Time continues to change. It is never static. Situations will change. Societies will change. But the basic foundation, I submit, and that is, the political stability-honest, efficient and an incorruptible political leadership-is paramount to the future well-being of Singapore, and that is, if we are to continue to enjoy our good standard of living, our good government and of course as an independent, sovereign entity or nation.

    I fully subscribe to what the First Deputy Prime Minister has said earlier this afternoon, that he will take those suggestions and comments into consideration vis-a-vis the make-up pay, the performance bonus and so on. These are technicalities. I think what is important is to get that team and that is where we should never be deflected from. The third team is important. The dollars and cents, the technicalities of it, I think, are not. But I accept what he has brought up this afternoon. Thank you, Sir.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Clarification, Sir. Mr Ng Kah Ting mentioned something about my mistake concerning the PPSO and ISA. I believe he must know that the essence of the PPSO and ISA is the same-it is the special branch. I mentioned the ISA merely to make it easier for the people present here in the Chamber to understand what it is all about. The other thing he mentioned was that there were no trump cards being used. Maybe he has forgotten that Mr Lee

Column: 818

Kuan Yew used the PPSO to arrest many of our colleagues in the Operation Cold Storage in which more than 140 or 150 of our leaders were arbitrarily arrested. And, of course, we found it very difficult after that.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I knew that the NCMP would come out and say that-don't mix up the ISA with PPSO because basically it is the same. I say, no. Because in 1958, PAP was not in power. It was the Lim Yew Hock government. That is the difference I am trying to make. So let us not go around in this wild political rhetoric. I understand that. That is why I have deliberately made that point.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: It is always easier to pass the buck.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry and Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Chairman, Sir, several of the Members have laid stress on the importance of idealism as a value in public service. I agree with them. It is important-if we believe this is just a job to be done, we should not be here. And I think most of us would not be here were it not for a sense of service, mission, a sense of duty, something which has to be done. I say that not only of the Ministers but also of the MPs, and even of the Opposition MPS and the Non-Constituency MPs, who have clearly put considerable heart and soul into their political careers, successful or unsuccessful as they may have been.

    So there is idealism. I do not think anybody in Singapore joins politics for salaries. I suspect in other countries too, they do not join politics for the salary; sometimes they do it because they mix business with politics. But that is an extra-curricular remuneration, not a formal salary; it does not apply in Singapore. In Singapore there are many easier ways of earning a living and having a peaceful life, doing well for oneself, without engaging in acrimonious discussions and soul-searching debates as to what is the right thing to do for the country.

    Idealism is a good word. Will it, by itself, be a sufficient policy guide for establishing a workable system? I do not think so. Whether idealism, by itself, will bring in the right people into politics, is not a

Column: 819

matter of theory and rhetoric; but is an empirical fact. If what you say is true, are the right people coming in?

    Our society has changed. We are no longer in a revoluntion situation. We do not have riots and great uncertainty every day. Able young men do not fear for their entire futures, if they do not do something about the destiny of the nation. It is so peaceful that many people believe nothing need be done in order to maintain it like this. It will of its own accord sail on calmly, minus auto pilot, and never hit a rock.

    In such an environment, nobody believes that Singapore's future depends on his entering politics or not entering politics. They have options. They can calculate. You have so many Ministers, why don't you continue? You are doing a reasonable job. From time to time, we may be unhappy with what you do, but overall, please carry on. Leave us to look after our own careers. We are grateful that you have created so many opportunities and so many attractive routes of advancement.

    It is a very natural, reasonable, understandable human reaction. We see it each time we look for an MP. We see it even more each time we look for Ministers, and I think the Opposition Members know this. Dr Lee said, if we need good people in politics, why not get the old generation leaders back? Because that was a different generation, a different situation, different compulsions, and different results. But are the young men the same?

    You have heard the Prime Minister talking about the Civil Service. The argument of service applies not just to politicians, but the civil servants too. It is the same argument - that civil servants ought to feel a sense of mission, purpose, making a difference; charting policies, being close to the centre of power, psychic pleasures and fulfilments, empty stomachs go unnoticed. If that were so, why are the civil servants leaving? Dr Ow earlier asked how many Permanent Secretaries have left-fortunately, none. But unfortunately there may not be many Permanent Secretaries left, because they are leaving long before they become Per-

Column: 820

manent Secretaries or, for that matter, Deputy Secretaries. Likewise, with Judges. It is an honour to serve, yes. You have heard how it works in Britain. In Singapore, Mr Goh has shown you how the CJ ranks about 50th amongst lawyers, Judges rank about 80th, in terms of remuneration. So, what do we do? Have national service for lawyers? Draft them to serve as judges? We appoint Judicial Commissioners. Even Judicial Commissioners feel the same pressure to return to the Bar to practise, because under the rules after three years on the bench they can no longer practise. Therefore, "let us get back because, otherwise, I lose my ability to make a living for myself." That is why the Minister for Law some weeks ago informed the House that we are considering amending the Legal Profession Act to allow Judicial Commissioners to go back to practice, even after more than three years as JCs, provided they do not then appear before the court, because that is awkward - having sat on the Bench, to appear before ex colleagues and argue cases before them.

    These are the individuals, this is the society, from which we have to find leaders. You may call it materialism. But it is the motivating force which has pushed Singapore forward and made Singapore different. Our people want to get ahead, they fight for the best for themselves and their family, and calculate their career options rationally. Therefore, we have growth and progress, and therefore we can afford to pay those whom we need to enter the public service.

    Mr Chiam raised the question: What is the basis for paying those who enter the public service? I think he has a point. What the Minister can contribute is huge compared to what you can pay him. He makes one wrong decision, 30,000 workers will go unemployed for three or four years. We just had one recession. 30,000 times three or four years to one, and the NCMP cavils over salary ratio of 30:1. The contribution, and for that matter the potential subtraction from the national wealth and welfare, is enormous compared to what you can pay.

    However, this is not an argument therefore to pay Ministers billions of dollars a

Column: 821

year, or even millions of dollars a year. What is a fair basis? We believe the fair basis is, roughly speaking, opportunity cost. What is the man earning outside? How much can he earn? We offer him about that, probably a little less. He does not come in to get wealthy, but he comes in without suffering too much pain. Is it a ratio-30:1? Yes, as it is in China. But let me ask the question a different way. If workers had money to put into a bank, do they put the money into a bank whose managers is paid peanuts? Or should they put their money into a bank with a top manager paid, maybe as these figures show, $200,000 a month, in order that their money be well looked after and safe, and the workers' savings are protected? If that is so of their savings, what more of their future?

    Other people have tried to limit the ratio of top to bottom salaries, Vietnam for one. I do not know if the NCMP might have read what one Vietnamese Minister said recently. It would have made painful reading for him, but I think it was Nguyen Van Linh in Delhi who said: "What's all this? People are criticizing us (speaking about Vietnam) for having differentials in salary. We have had 30 years of equality in salary, and all it is has led to is misery, stagnation and decay. So let's not talk about equality of salary." This is a Politburo member speaking, another fallen idol. Do we have to go through the same trauma to reach the same conclusion?

    Some would object that if you pay Ministers the right pay, you might get the wrong men in. Maybe. Those who cannot make a living elsewhere would like to come in at that salary. But at least we will have the choice of turning them away and choosing the men who are fit to enter. If we pay peanuts, and why stop at whatever it is ($20,000 now), why not push it back to $2,000 and make a greater show of sacrifice? You will still find an applicant knocking at your door saying, "I would like to become a Minister." Do you take him for his great nobleness of heart? Or do you wonder why he needs a job? Should you not ask what he intends to do after becoming a Minister? There are countries where Ministers are paid very little. They have no shortage of applicants, nor do

Column: 822

those who become Ministers particularly suffer from poverty.

    So what should we do? I suggest the right thing to do is to be fair, and watch what the private sector offers. We do not have to match the top banker for all Ministers. But if we have to pay one key man to get him to serve , for example, as Minister for Finance, then even if we have to offer something like it, we should.

    Several Members have spoken up against performance bonuses and make-up pay. We have discussed this in Cabinet. The First Deputy Prime Minister has asked me to explain this because he will speak about other subjects later. The Ministers work as a team. Everybody on the team performs and contributes. Those who do not should be out. But those who are in, while all work, not all carry equal load. It is a reality. I think it is known, it is acknowledged. And if we are honest with ourselves, it is so. Therefore, we need mechanisms to distinguish between those who carry the heavier loads and do more than the rest. Hence, promotion grades for the Parliamentary Secretary, Ministers of State and Ministers. Similarly, we have performance bonuses in order that in between promotions, and from year to year, we can make a distinction between the man who is doing all right and the person who is doing outstanding, but is not due for promotion yet.

    Does it mean hard decisions? Yes. It is always awkward. But it is no more awkward than for Permanent Secretaries. They also have this official myth, if you like,that every Permanent Secretary is equal to every other Permanent Secretary. It does not matter whether the Ministry is huge or tiny, it is supposedly the same job, the same status, and the same importance. It is no different from distinguishing between officers on the General Staff, between the person who is in charge of operations, or plans, or manpower. There are differences in the responsibility, in the judgment required, in the size of the job. If we want civil servants to evaluate officers honestly, then politicians ought to have the courage and the integrity to have ourselves also similarly judged. I do not believe that either the Prime Minister or the First Deputy Prime Minister would

Column: 823

have the slightest hesitation in implementing this scheme and judging his Ministers, to their faces. And I think, likewise, the Ministers and the Parliamentary Secretaries are man enough to accept such assessments and know where they stand. To pretend otherwise is convenient, but I do not think it is honest.

    As for make-up pay, there are circumstances when we will need it. In recent general elections, the only Ministers of State who have come in and received a pay rise are the ex -civil servants or ex-Army officers. Everybody else who has come from the private sector has done so at a pay cut, in some cases, a substantial pay out. All right, we have managed to do it with these few. Do we want to continue doing so?

    We have revised the Minister of State's pay somewhat. But we cannot push it all the way up. Neither do we want to appoint such a person to be a Minister straightaway, because a successful executive might not make it as a Minister. So when he comes in as a Minister of State in his mid-30s or early 40s, make-up pay provides one way to bridge the gap and ease the transition.

    The other circumstance in which we will need it is when we have a key Minister's post vacant and we must bring in somebody from the very top of the private sector pinnacle. We need a Minister for Finance. We need a Minister for Law. Not any Minister can do the job. You need in one case a lawyer, in the other somebody who is very familiar with the world of finance. And if he is anywhere on this table, how will you persuade him to enter? In fact, if he is not on this table, questions should be asked why we are taking him at all! Why should we, in order to accommodate such a person, correspondingly inflate every other Minister's salary to the same level? Is it necessary? Is it justifiable? We do not think so. Therefore, a system of make up pay is established. Of course, if we bring in a top banker and then leave him as Minister of State for two terms, say in the Ministry of Education or Law, questions might be raised why the Government

Column: 824

is doing such a thing. Is he really worth all that money? But I do not foresee this Government acting in such an irrational way.

    Finally, relativities with the Civil Service. The Prime Minister has already touched on this, so I do not want to go into detail. But there was a piece in the Sunday Times on 12th March by Tan Sai Siong, which said that basically civil servants were pencil sharpeners for Ministers. So why not just pay Ministers and skip the pencil sharpeners?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is true that in Singapore the Ministers take the lead and the civil servants provide the support. I think that is right, and it will continue. It can, provided we continue to get Ministers who are fit to give instructions to Permanent Secretaries. If the Minister is not fit to give instructions to his PS, the relationship will change overnight. The PS will not be making speeches here and neither are the same policies going to be presented, because if the speech cannot be made, the policy cannot be carried.

    Having said that, it is important for Ministers to be backed up with a strong staff from the Permanent Secretaries downwards. They are not pencil sharpeners, but provide proper staff work, research and well-considered options. Then the political direction can be interpreted and implemented in sensible, rational ways, which will leave MPs with a minimum duty of writing letters to Ministers on behalf of their constituents. To do that, the Administrative Service cannot be at two-thirds strength.
